Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 54226-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
August 2020 
 
 
Mongolia: Strengthening Institutional Capacity to 
Respond to COVID-19 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) to the Government of Mongolia will 
support capacity building and skills for detection and surveillance of the coronavirus disease 
(COVID-19) in Mongolia. The TA will achieve this through capacity development training and 
information dissemination. The proposed TA activities will be coordinated across government 
agencies.1  
 
2.  The TA is aligned with the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) country partnership strategy 
for Mongolia, 2017–20202 and ADB’s Strategy 2030 operational priorities to enhance human 
capital, provide better health for all, and strengthen governance and institutional capacity.3 The 
TA is also aligned with the Mongolia State Policy on Health 2017–2026,4 which reaffirms 
sustained commitment to improving health services and outcomes. The TA is an emergency 
response to the ongoing COVID-19 crisis.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Mongolia’s response to COVID-19. COVID-19 first emerged in the People’s Republic of 
China (PRC) in December 2019. While the PRC attempted to contain the virus, air travel and 
interconnectivity during the initial days of the virus’ emergence contributed to its international 
spread. Landlocked and sharing a long southern border with the PRC, Mongolia responded swiftly 
to the rapidly emerging situation and, by mid-January 2020, the government instituted strict 
emergency measures to prevent the virus from spreading. These measures included international 
and national travel restrictions; nonessential business closure; public awareness campaigns; 
restrictions on public gatherings, meetings, and celebrations; closure of schools; and rapid 
preparation of hospitals to deal with the expected emergency. The swift and rapid action slowed 
the virus spread and Mongolia has managed to mitigate community transmission. 
 
4.  An  estimated  20%  of  the  population  are  at  "high  risk"  to  contract  COVID-19. 
Mongolia is considered a high risk country because of severe weather conditions, prevalence of 
respiratory  diseases  accounting  for  a  high  burden  of  disease,  and  20%  of  the  population 
estimated as high risk because of age and comorbidities. The World Health Organization (WHO) 
evaluation of core capacities in Mongolia indicates that its preparedness to respond to health 
threats is limited. WHO recommended increased funding and support for public health workforce 
training, surveillance and risk assessments, laboratory systems, and public health emergency 
preparedness. Recommendations also included strengthening pandemic influenza preparedness 
planning; sharing risk assessments across sectors; mapping potential hazards; maintaining 
stockpiles; developing surge capacity during emergencies; improving active and passive disease 
surveillance of new and emerging diseases; and developing capacity for medical, nursing, and 
allied health staff to surveil and diagnose emerging health threats.5 
 
1  Other agencies might include the National Emergency Management Agency, the National Center for Communicable 
Diseases, border military services, customs, and immigration services. 
2  ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: Mongolia, 2017–2020—Sustaining Inclusive Growth in a Period of 
Economic Difficulty. Manila. The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on  
12 August 2020. 
3  ADB. 2017. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 1: Addressing Remaining Poverty and Reducing Inequalities, 
2019–2024. Manila. ADB. 2017. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 2: Accelerating Progress in Gender 
Equality, 2019–2024. Manila; and ADB. 2017. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 6: Strengthening 
Governance and Institutional Capacity. Manila.  
4  Government of Mongolia. 2017. State Policy on Health 2017–2026. Ulaanbaatar. Approved by Government of 
Mongolia Resolution No. 24, 18 January 2017. 
5  WHO. 2017. Joint External Evaluation of International Health Regulation Core Capacities of Mongolia. Geneva.

2 
5.  A number of specialized agencies support national pandemic response efforts. In 
addition to the Ministry of Health, the General Agency for Specialized Inspection (GASI), the 
National Emergency Management Agency, the National Center for Communicable Diseases, 
border military services, customs, and immigration services all support the pandemic response 
efforts. As the national inspection agency responsible for all entry points in the country, GASI is 
one of the most important agencies engaged in pandemic response efforts. GASI inspectors are 
responsible for managing and containing infectious diseases at border-crossing points and 
reducing any potential vectors for transmission (i.e., goods and materials) at key land and sea 
ports. To date, all of Mongolia’s COVID-19 cases have been imported through borders. GASI has 
been critical in managing these threats and instituting measures to shut down the country’s 
connectivity to mitigate the spread. Other supporting agencies are also highly vulnerable as the 
first points of contact for new cases and making them critical for a coordinated and effective 
national response.  
 
6.  A gap exists in training and capacity building for COVID-19 surveillance, detection, 
and mitigation. GASI, border military services, customs, and immigration services are not 
specialized health agencies. However, they play a central role in the country’s response, making 
coordination and their understanding of infectious disease outbreaks critical to managing and 
mitigating the risks. Yet, no formalized training in effective infectious disease response is available 
for their staff members. Training in infectious disease control, risk communication, surveillance, 
and prevention for GASI’s and other agencies’ staff members is, therefore, a critical gap that 
positively impacts effective COVID-19 response. Some key gaps in capacity building include 
surveillance  of  emerging  infectious  diseases,  infection  prevention  and  control,  and  risk 
management. Targeted capacity building activities for key agencies will assist Mongolia to mount 
a successful COVID-19 response. 
 
7.  ADB support for COVID-19 response. The Government of Mongolia has requested ADB 
support to tackle the COVID-19 pandemic. ADB engagement in the health sector has been 
significant and impactful. ADB has responded to Mongolia’s immediate need by repurposing 
$1.4 million loan savings to purchase equipment and laboratory diagnostics to detect and screen 
for COVID-19; reallocating $75,000 to purchase screening equipment at selected border crossing 
points; providing $1.0 million assistance from the Asia Pacific Disaster Response Fund to procure 
emergency medical equipment; mobilizing a small-scale technical assistance of $225,000 for 
health  sector  training  in  emergency  response;  providing  an  emergency  assistance  loan  of  
$30.0 million to upgrade hospital infection, prevention, and control practices, establish and 
manage a centralized stockpile of medicines and medical equipment, and improve capacity to 
diagnose COVID-19; and mobilizing a COVID-19 Rapid Response Program of $100.0 million to 
mitigate the severe economic and health impacts of the pandemic.6 
 
 
6  Repurposing ($1.4 million) for ADB. Mongolia Fifth Health Sector Development Project; Reallocation of $75,000 from 
ADB. Mongolia: Regional Improvement of Border Services; Grant assistance ($1.0 million) for ADB. Mongolia: 
COVID-19 Emergency Response Project; Support for training ($225,000) under ADB. Mongolia: Support for 
Improving the Preparedness and Response to Novel Coronavirus Outbreak; Emergency assistance loan for 
additional financing ($30.0 million) for ADB. Mongolia: Fifth Health Sector Development Project; and Countercyclical 
support of $100.0 million for ADB. Mongolia: COVID-19 Rapid Response Program.

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: public health threats effectively addressed 
(footnote 4). The TA will have the following outcome: management and institutional response to 
COVID-19 and other emerging infectious diseases strengthened.7 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: Knowledge and skills in disease surveillance and outbreak response 
improved. The TA will provide training to key GASI personnel (central and local) and other 
agencies involved in response, such as border military services, customs, and immigration 
services, in specific areas, including, but not limited to (i) prevention and control of infections;  
(ii) appropriate use of personal protective equipment; (iii) management of infectious individuals in 
a non-discriminatory manner; (iv) management of potentially infectious or hazardous physical 
objects  during  outbreaks;  (v)  leveraging  of  digital  technology  to  support  better  disease 
surveillance, especially in border areas; and (vi) development of methods and joint strategies to 
identify  early  warning  signs  of  COVID-19  and  other  infectious  diseases.  ADB  will  hold 
consultations  and  capacity  development  workshops,  facilitate  peer-to-peer  learning  through 
knowledge exchange, and strengthen collaboration with technical agencies such as WHO and 
the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) to deliver trainings.8 National experts will be 
engaged as resource persons to facilitate the trainings. The TA will identify key agency staff 
members to undergo "training of trainers," to ensure that institutional memory is maintained and 
trainers can continue to conduct cascade training even after TA completion. Under this output, a 
background report on managing infectious diseases for frontline government agencies will also 
be produced. 
 
10.  Output 2: Risk communication for COVID-19 supported.9 The TA will support risk 
communication and increase public awareness about the pandemic. Support for the design and 
implementation of a risk communication strategy will include development and production of 
materials and dissemination approaches. The TA will (i) produce a digital and print educational 
outreach campaign on COVID-19, (ii) inform the public of ongoing risks and behavioral mitigation 
strategies, (iii) prepare a dissemination strategy, and (iv) support dissemination of the campaign 
with GASI.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $400,000, of which $350,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6). The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix  2.  The  Government  of  Mongolia  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of 
counterpart staff, office space, and other in-kind contributions.  
 
 
7  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
8  This could be explored since ADB has a memorandum of understanding with UNICEF. UNICEF and ADB. 2018. 
Memorandum of Understanding. Bali. 
9  Risk communication refers to the exchange of real-time information and advice between experts and individuals 
facing threats to their health and socioeconomic well-being.

4 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  ADB will administer the TA, in close coordination with GASI, the executing agency for the 
TA. The Urban and Social Sectors Division of the East Asia Department will select, supervise, 
and evaluate consultants and organize capacity building activities. 
 
13.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  21 August 2020–31 July 2022  
Executing agency  General Agency for Specialized Inspection 
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB 
Individual: Individual  Public health expert  $54,500 
consultant selection   (national, 9 person-months) 
Individual: Individual  Project coordinator  $44,600 
consultant selection   (national, 12 person-
months) 
Individual: Resource  Facilitators and resource  $44,000 
person selection  persons (national) 
Firm: Consultants'  Communication agency  $60,000 
qualification selection  (national, 10 person-
months) 
Disbursement  The TA resources will be disbursed following ADB's Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2020, as amended from time 
to time).  
ADB = Asian Development Bank, TA = technical assistance. 
Source: ADB. 
 
14.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated procurement staff instructions.10 
ADB  will engage individual consultants, facilitators, and resource persons to organize and 
manage trainings and workshops under output 1; and engage a national consulting firm to deliver 
activities under output 2. Considering the highly specialized expertise required, consultants' 
qualification selection will be used to select the firm which will develop a COVID-19 awareness 
campaign. ADB will evaluate the TA progress through biannual review missions and monitor 
performance targets and indicators outlined in the design and monitoring framework. 
 
15.  Due diligence. No civil works or environmental safeguards will be triggered during TA 
implementation. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $350,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Mongolia for Strengthening Institutional Capacity to Respond to COVID-19, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.
 
10 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).
